name: Eiffel Tower
description: An iconic iron lattice tower built for the 1889 World's Fair, offering panoramic views of Paris from its observation decks.
address: Champ de Mars, 5 Avenue Anatole France, 75007 Paris, France

name: Louvre Museum
description: The world's largest art museum and a historic monument in Paris, home to masterpieces like the Mona Lisa and the Venus de Milo.

name: Musée d'Orsay
description: A museum housed in a Beaux-Arts railway station, showcasing French art from 1848 to 1914, including Impressionist masterpieces.
address: 1 Rue de la Légion d'Honneur, 75007 Paris, France

name: Notre-Dame Cathedral
description: A masterpiece of Gothic architecture famous for its sculptures, stained glass, and bell towers. Currently under restoration.
address: 6 Parvis Notre-Dame - Pl. Jean-Paul II, 75004 Paris, France

name: Sainte-Chapelle
description: A royal chapel built in the 13th century, renowned for its stunning stained-glass windows depicting biblical scenes.

name: Palace of Versailles
description: A lavish royal residence outside Paris, famous for its Hall of Mirrors, gardens, and role in French history.

name: Arc de Triomphe
description: A monumental arch honoring those who fought and died for France in the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars.
address: Place Charles de Gaulle, 75008 Paris, France

name: Panthéon
description: A neoclassical mausoleum housing the remains of distinguished French citizens such as Voltaire, Rousseau, and Marie Curie.

name: Musée Rodin
description: A museum dedicated to the works of French sculptor Auguste Rodin, set in a beautiful mansion with a sculpture garden.

name: Les Invalides
description: A complex containing museums and monuments related to France's military history, including Napoleon Bonaparte’s tomb.

name: Palais Garnier
description: A 19th-century opera house renowned for its opulent architecture and as the inspiration for 'The Phantom of the Opera'.

name: Petit Palais
description: An art museum built for the 1900 Exposition Universelle, housing fine arts collections from the Renaissance to the 20th century.

name: Grand Palais
description: A historic site and exhibition hall known for its glass-domed roof and hosting major art and cultural events.
address: 3 Avenue du Général Eisenhower, 75008 Paris, France

name: Musée de l'Orangerie
description: An art gallery featuring Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings, including Monet's famous Water Lilies series.

name: Conciergerie
description: A former royal palace and prison, known for housing Marie Antoinette before her execution during the French Revolution.

name: Place de la Concorde
description: One of Paris's major public squares, famous for its Egyptian obelisk and its role in the French Revolution.
address: Place de la Concorde, 75008 Paris, France

name: Montmartre
description: A historic hilltop district known for its artistic heritage, cobbled streets, and the Basilica of Sacré-Cœur.

name: Sacré-Cœur Basilica
description: A Roman Catholic basilica with a striking white exterior and one of the best panoramic views of Paris.
address: 35 Rue du Chevalier de la Barre, 75018 Paris, France

name: Musée Picasso
description: A museum dedicated to Pablo Picasso's works, housed in the historic Hôtel Salé in the Marais district.

name: Musée Carnavalet
description: A museum dedicated to the history of Paris, located in two historic mansions in the Marais district.

name: Père Lachaise Cemetery
description: The largest cemetery in Paris, final resting place of famous figures like Jim Morrison, Oscar Wilde, and Édith Piaf.

name: Palais Royal
description: A historic palace with beautiful gardens and arcades, once home to royalty and now housing government offices.

name: Pont Alexandre III
description: A Beaux-Arts style bridge, lavishly decorated with lamps and statues, connecting the Champs-Élysées quarter with Invalides.

name: Place des Vosges
description: The oldest planned square in Paris, surrounded by red-brick houses and a favorite spot for locals and tourists.

name: Musée du Quai Branly – Jacques Chirac
description: A museum showcasing indigenous art and cultures from Africa, Asia, Oceania, and the Americas, in a striking modern building.
